text:
this 25.6oz bottle is about 3 years old and labeled Limited Edition and 8.3% abv

poured a hazy medium amber with a nice 1/2" head that has minimal retention. the aromas are sweet malts, strong maple, spices and cherry. there is also a hint of alcohol, after all this one is 8.3%.
the sweetness of the maple and the malts dominate this beer. there is plenty of cherry flavors too along with a bit of caramel. the bitterness kicks in towards the end as it hits the palate with slight alcohol warmth.
this beer has med to full body, creamy and rich texture, medium carbonation and minimal astringency.
the finish is long with lots of maple sweetness and lingering bitterness and alcohol.
overall not my style of beer but I can see how some other drinkers will love this one. its complex and rich. 
the good news is that it has aged incredibly well. there are NO signs of any oxidation or other over-aging off flavors or aromas.
Bottle. Pours clear copper. Aroma of vanilla, caramel and wood. Taste is sweet with a lot of vanilla coming through with some oakiness.

The aroma of this beer reminded me of beer fueled sick. The taste is overly sweet. I i found the sweetness to quite sickly in combination with the woody taste, making it almost acrid. A bit biscuity flavour but lacks any defining malt characteristics, probably due to the cloying sweetness. One of Innis & Gunns poorer examples

Thanks to Viesturs, 
Sweet, very sweet, malty emphasys. Notes of BA are almost absent in aroma, in flavor also minimal. Reminds more of doppelbock. Malt combination is boring, like there is no direction or some character- just light malty with some medium toasted malts color. Foam disappears fast. Above medium body.
Clear brown colour. Flavour has an intense sweetness from the maple syrup. Very light woody dryness. Overall a pleasant taste but too sweet.

Pours a clear copper colour with a thick head which dissipates quickly. Sweetish aromas of caramel and vanilla. The taste is sweet, with the maple syrup quite well-blended into the other sweet, caramel flavours. Some oakiness (from the cherrywood?) and hints of vanilla and berries. Rather too sweet to be easily drinkable, and rather under-carbonated. The artwork is nice, but the beer is not particularly memorable.

Bottle from Aldi, reddish dark brown with a fast-settling head, punchy sweet and alcoholic nose with notes of maple syrup. Initially rather too sweet, a woody, toasty and drier midbody then moderates the sweetness a little, but not enough. The finish is an intriguing but not entirely appealing mix of cloying and dry-bitter with a vanilla note. The painting on the box is excellent, though.

Bottle from aldi like every I and g Ive tasted it flatters to deceive sounds good on the bottle smell the part then is flat and overly sweet no more I and g for me no matter how much they tempt me in with delightful sounding concoctions
25.2.2015. Clear ruby. Aroma has caramel, oak, vanilla, berries. Not overly sweet oaky. Taste has berries, caramel malts, oak, slight alcohol. I quite like this.
330ml bottle @ 11th Shrewsbury Bottle Share, Feb 15. Apparently aged - thanks Mike! Sour kola kubes aroma. Taste continues.. not actually too bad, but still bad.
Steady aroma - pours clear copper with inch white head which soon disappears to a thin line. No fizz. Very smooth and sweet - though too sweet for me.

330 ml clear bottle in cardboard box, from Vinmonopolet. BB July 2014. ABV is 8.3%. Cloudy reddish amber colour, pours fizzy with a small short-lived head, slightly off-white. Sweetish aroma with notes of caramel, raisins and dark dried fruits, notes of "oak" (cherrywood, of course). Sweet flavour, too sweet maybe, loads of caramel, maple syrup and dark dried fruits, also cherrywood, minimal hops. Okay, but probably not something I would buy again.

BROWN bottle from Aldi. It pours clear mahogany brown with a small beige head. The nose is pretty damn sweet, malt-driven, brown bread, wood, treacle, syrup, caramel and cola. The taste is sweet, toasty, caramel, cola, maple syrup, plenty of vanilla, wood, sugary and some alcohol heat with a sweet, sticky finish. Medium body, fine carbonation and sticky mouth-feel. Tastes a lot like coke vanilla, except gives you a boost. Too sweet for sure, but not as bad as I had feared!

(Bottle 7.4% not 8.3% ABV) Clear golden amber, small off-white head. Nice aroma of caramel with vanilla and maple hints. Medium body with good carbonation. Great taste - the sweetness has very interesting notes, I would have guessed at honey, but presumably its maple syrup. There are some gentle wooded notes adding balance and plenty of interest to the taste. Theres some pleasant rather restrained bitterness in the finish which is sustained and takes with it some of the interesting and unusual flavours. An excellent and unusual beer.

Au nez, on reconnait immédiatement les arômes typiques de I&G, soit le malt bien sucré et de fût de chêne. Un arôme de sirop dérable semble vouloir se démarquer aussi.
En bouche, le malt explose suivis du sucre et de notes de bois. On perçois des touches de caramel, sucre à la crème et de houblon. Lamertume et très courte et douce.
Très bonne bière encore un fois de I&G. Très bien balancé et aucune trace dalcool malgré le taux relativement élevé.
Bottle from Aldi. Pours deep amber with a small off white head. Sweet flavour with fruit and moderate ginger spice. Not bad.

330ml bottle. 7.4% ABV.
Deep Copper Cherry colour with off white to tan head, that doesnt last, Aroma of toffee, treacle, taste of toffee, roasted barley and malty notes, crisp sweet finish and quite pleasing.
bottle, Tesco Honiton. Golden colour, fluffy white head. Malty with vanilla and a touch of wood, also some honey there.
330mk bottle. Pours dark copper with a beige head that doesnt last long. Aroma is caramel, wood, whiskey. Taste is syrupy sweet with hints of maple syrup.

330ml bottle pours a deep ruddy clear ale with a smooth creamy light head. Aroma, caramel, fragrant, some hint of whisky. Taste, sweet, honey, caramel, liquor whisky, thought there might be some bitterness somewhere but pretty much in the background. Rather pleasant though one to savour as a single.

33cl bottle from Aldi, Bracknell. ABV 7.4% A bright golden amber colour with no head but lots of carbonation; rather subdued aroma - some wood but little else; the taste is a confusion of sweetness from the maple syrup and vanilla from the wood; the finish has a lingering toasty sweetness. Rather unbalanced overall.

7.4%, and in a brown bottle. I can?t stop drinking absolutely superb winter beers at the moment. This is incredibly sweet and beautifully treacley -sugar that?s gone way beyond caramel but stopped short of burnt. Strong notes of antique wood, leather, melted ice in a whisky glass. No head.

Bottle from Booths, Media City. Cloudy and copper-amber in colour with next to no head. Has a sweet nose with some fruit, but more sugar. Sweet fruited flavours but very strong tasting with the special maturity evident.

330ml bottle in a box, bought at Vinmonopolet Langnes. Dense, fawn-coloured lacing-head resting on top of a clear amber coloured body. Vanilla oak on the nose, hints of cherry and bread. Taste profile of cherry, vanilla, and wood joined by dried fruits. Mid-sweet tail. Rounded, integrated alcohol warming down the throat. Likable, however a tad to sweet in the long run (Tromsø 22.11.2014).
33cl bottle. Small white layer. Hazy oak dark pilsener color. Aroma is oak, cognac, raisins. Taste is sugar, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, wood. Very sweet.
Bottle at Craig. Sweet cherry on nose, taste is sweet, cherry, vanilla, fizzy, way too sickly sweet.

Bottle. Golden copper colour with offwhite head. Aroma and taste of sweet malt, raisins, cherry, vanilla and a bit dark sugar. Light bitter and fresh crisp mouthfeel. Woody finish. Great scottish ale.

Unique shaped clear 750ml bottle. To the dome. Filtered amber-orange body. Big foamy off-white head. Sweet barrel(?) tones in the aroma...think cinnamon-orange liqueur. The flavors and body is mellower, thankfully, which the maple syrup plays a major role in. Should have definitely saved this one for a tasting, a whole bottle is not really that desirable. Comes off too "malt beverage", as opposed to classic Scottish Ale. In line with the rest of the Innis and Gunn releases gimmicky overtones are hard to ignore. Sweet brown sugar rum in the finish. Not the worst alcoholic beverage, but not a great beer.

bottle, 7.4% ABV, best before February 2015. small head fades quick. mid-High carbonation. Sweet ale aroma. moderately sweet, alcohol finish and wood - the Cherrywood I guess. quite light body. not as sweet, rich and full bodied as some scotch ales Ive had. not bad.

Bottle from Tesco. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin whispy head. The aroma is sweet malt yeast and cherry wood I guess. The flavour is moderate sweet, light bitter with a sweet woody resin hop palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation.

33cl bottle courtesy of JMGreenUK and shared with 2 brewing buddies.
Thin creamy white head. Clear amber pour. Nice woody aftertaste
On bottle from Vinmonopolet Norway. Copper colored , ok foam. Aromas of caramel , toffee, some malt. Medium body & complexity.,on the sweet side. Not really my favourite

Bottled 330ml. -from random Tesco in Glasgow. Clear amber coloured, small off-white head, toasted malt in the nose. Toasted malt, caramel, dried fruits and notes of aok and discreet touch of cherries in the finish. Hint of alcohol and wood in the finish as well.

Bottle. Rich red-amber ale with a thick cream head. Nose is malty with a touch of wood and syrup notes. Taste is vanilla, cherry, confection. A touch of alcohol burn in the finish, but its smooth, vanilla cherry. Rather tasty. Rather toasty.

Deep orange with a red tint and a tan lasting, lacy head. Smells inline anything Ive smelt before. Smells of wood and maple syrup, cherry and caramel. Sweet taste at first with a bitter woody centre softened by berry and some spice with a sweet honey and cherry finish. Lingering alcohol on the finish, I like that it tastes new and different. But its not incredible. Still sweet and nice enough to drink.

Boxed 330ml bottle with an ABV of 7.4%: BBD Feb 2015, poured into a Gordons thistle shaped glass on 24th Sep 2014. Looked great in the glass, clear, clean and colourful. The full foaming head highlighting the mahogany hue to the body. Really sweet aroma and taste, bubblegum and syrup notes to the fore. There is also a slight cherry feel to the whole brew but the syrup flavour rules throughout the beer. My sweet tooth liked it but I would have prefered the aging to have been given more of a chance to come through, even if I am not a big fan of cherry flavoured beers. A lot better than I expected to be honest.

Aroma: cherrywood, dark malts. Appearance: clear ruby color, white head. Taste: low bitterness, cherrywood notes, oak, slightly sweet and well-balanced. Palate: medium body and medium carbonation. Overall: interesting beer with a huge impact of cherrywood.

Transfer from BA review on 8-11-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The brew pours a copper-amber color with a billowy just off white head. The head had a lighter level of retention, fading rather fast to leave light lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma was sweet being a mix of darker fruits of cherry and fig as well as a maple syrup and caramel smell. Along with these sweeter smells so too comes some nice oak and biscuity malt aromas. A little bit of alcohol and spice also comes to the nose creating a warming sweet woodsy smell overall.

 Taste  The taste starts out with a sweeter caramel and lighter dark fruit flavors of cherry, plum and fig. Along with the sweeter flavors upfront are some biscuit malty flavors as well as a little bit of oak. The oak grows stronger while the biscuit loses strength as the taste moves on. Along with the biscuit fading so too does some of the caramel only to be replaced by a more candied sugar, toffee and maple syrup taste. In the end the oakiness mixed with some alcohol booziness to give a sweeter whisky like taste which when combined with all the fruit, sugar and light malty tastes ends up leaving a smooth, sweet, and warm taste to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel- The body of the brew is on the thicker and creamier side with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. The thickness is quite nice for the sweeter flavors of the brew with the lighter carbonation helping to create a more warming feel in light of the boozy and oaky flavors of the brew.

 Overall  A rather enjoyable brew overall. It is sweet of maple, fruit and other sugars but is balanced out by some of the wood, boozy and biscuit malt flavors of the brew. A nice one to give a go to.

Tastes like every other Innis & Gunn beer - malty, syrupy, sweet, etc. However this one is better than usual because the typical I&G oak palate rape isnt occurring; instead a nice velvety flavour from the cherrywood comes through and fades into the maple syrup and malts quite nicely.

Piłem Seasonal Edition, 7,4 alc. 330 ml. Ciemno czerwony, ciemno bursztynowy kolor. Srednia, brudno biała piana, ktora jednak szybko znika. Aromat: dębowy, trochę alkoholowy, charakterystyczne zapachy utlenienia. Smak: przyjemnie alkoholowy z charakterystycznym posmakiem w gardle. Rozgrzewające, zapełniające, przyjemne.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2014 A beautiful amber colour on the pour. Sweet cherry flavours on the initial sup followed by quite a sharp finish. A pleasant beer, would go well with dinner.

Very pleasant this one but probably not something I would have a session with. Very sweet, malty and as other people have stated, a lot of cherry. For all the sweet notes there is a bit of a tart finish which is nice, There is also a slight cough sweet/lozenge taste creeping through. I have another bottle of this which I will drink at a slightly higher temperature as Ive a feeling this has a bit more to offer.

DWF; Pours amber with a moderate lasting, lacing off-white head. Nose is shy malty, caramel, dark fruits and alcohol. Taste is more, moderate to heavy sweet, light bitter and barrel, somewhat lasting, Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation soft.
DWF. Copper with tan color head. Not mutch aroma. Tast a lot of oak,malt and caramel. Very good. Medium co2

300ml bottle, cheers Chris! Pours a clear orange amber with a thin white head. Aroma is very malty with a strong fruit element of syrupy overipe mangoes. Creamy rich mouthfeel and poor lacing. Mixed malts deliver a smooth and moist fruitloaf base with over ripe honeydew melon and mango. There is a short hop prickle present in the brief aftertaste but the malt asserts itself strongly in the finish. Rich and malty with the distinct I&G boozy warmth full in the mouth. This is a decent Scottish Strong Ale and I would love to try this in cask - like the rest of them!

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2015 First rate, 11/7/2014, rb score 7/3/8/3/16/ Bottle from Jim- cheers! Pours a copper colour with an audible fizz and a thin off-white head that swiftly vanishes. Smells sweet, almost sweet-shop sweet. Didnt expect cherrywood to actually taste of cherries but it definitely does. Maybe its auto-suggestion, but Im getting fresh cherries. And cherry cola. And some cough mixture. And a little light smoke. A light lemony hop flicks briefly across the tongue before an oak and vanilla finish. Its complex and warming and I like it, but its a little thin and the fizz is definitely too strong- sort that out and it could be great rather than just very good. 2nd rate 26/12/2014 rb score 8/3/7/3/14. Bottle, gift from Mum & Dad - cheers! Cherryade, Southern Comfort and the characteristic I&G vanilla & oak. Alcohol showed through a little too much. Score shown is the average of all rates.

330ml bottle. Pours a clear, ruby/amber with a white, half finger head. Aroma is big and malty. Dark fruits, caramel, slight sweetness, and a hint of cherry. Taste is malty but not overly sweet. Caramel, dark fruits, very slight tart cherry, a touch of maple, and some smooth barrel flavour. Short finish. Medium-full body with a medium carbonation. Slightly syrupy texture bust smooth as all hell with a dry finish. Overall a really nice beer. Smooth flavours of caramel and dark fruits with a hint of cherry and maple. A treat to have and probably my favorite Innis & Gunn.
330ml bottle from Oddbins, Shawlands. Orange brown ,reasonable head. Sweet whiskey malt aroma. Cloying syrupy malt flavour. Bitter sweet aftertaste. Usual Innis & Gunn type beer. Not for me.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2014 330 ml bottle, limited box edition, pours amber with a small head. Aroma has a more subtle oak flavour, and the cherrywood balances well with the Styrian fruity hop flavours, which are more prominent in this I&G than others Ive tried. Again the palate is thinner than I would like, but then these beers are cold conditioned which would explain the light, crisp palate. The beer is quite sweet, there are caramel notes, candy floss, cherries, mince pies. A bit thin, but nice.
Pours a dark brown colour, taste is sweet and caramel like, possibly due to the addition of maple syrup

Boxed bottle from Aldi. Steady fizzing bronze with a slim white foam. Sweet Bakewell and Amaretto aroma with candy floss and caramel boiled sweet. Thinnish red strong lager flavour with a cherry drop, cherry medicine, Allsorts, aniseed and marzipan character reminiscent of 5%+ Batemans or GK effort. Hints of blossom and rubber band. Pleasant to drink but a simplistic and overrated beer

330 ml bottle. Pours a clear, dark red amber colour with a small, short lived, off-white head. Sweet aroma of toasted malt, caramel and cherrywood. Sweet flavour of malt, caramel, cherrywood, maple syrup and mild vanilla with a semi dry, alcohol finish. Medium body with a sticky, oily texture and soft carbonation.
Another great brew from Innis & Gunn. A little spicier than their Rum Finish, but just as pleasurable

Pale clear red body with thin white head that soon fades. Nose cherry, bubblegum, oak and caramel. Taste sweet over bitter. Soft carbonation. Pretty short finish. One of I&Gs better beers but as ever slightly too sweet and not particularly complex.

Aroma is sweet cherry, malts and slight smokiness. Taste is rich sweet malts that has slight caramel, apple and dark cherry character. The maltiness is met by a very well balanced bitterness that finishes smoothly. Pretty solid overall. Body is a clear copper with a thin pearl head that retains fairly poorly.

A bronze beaut that needs to be a bit more buxom in the body. I&G slugs always seem to smell and taste pretty great and are always their own thing. A lot of caramel, maple, wood, leather, smoke, butterscotch and nut in this. I have never had an even mildly aggressively hopped beer from them, their focus seems to be aging and malt-forward flavour and they do it fairly well. I wish this one had a bit thicker texture.
Dunkel amber farve med lys beige skum. Lukt av malt, karamell og sherry. Smak av malt, karamell, og sherry. Vinmonopolet.
God duft av wiskey og kirsebær. Dunkel gulbrun farge. Lite skum, ring langs kant. Nydelig smak av wiskey, karamell og kirsebær. En fin litt søtlig ettersmak av karamell.
Bottle. Caramel, oak and cherry aromas. Sweet flavour, some unfermented sugars, caramel notes, medium carbonation and a fairly light mouthfeel. Good flavour, not a very full body.
Dark to medium amber with a large off white head. Aroma is nice larger and sweet. A sweet and malty beer with a creamy plate little to no hops flavors present.

Pours copper when first poured had large white head then dissipated very quick leaving nice lacing. Little lite on the noise, flavors of wood and molasses very nice 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is a little better than the typical I&G note. Malt and wood. Colour is a red amber with no real head. Taste is cherry, sweet. Feel is a bit thick but ok for the style.

Pours a clear medium pinkish orange with one finger of loose tan head diminishing gradually to a thin cap and spotty lacing. Nose is malty caramel, cherry fruit, wood, and slight vanilla. Taste is similar, dominated by sweet malt with a little cherry and wood. Mouth feel is medium bodied with low carbonation and a mildly bitter finish.

Like most I&G products, I find this on the sweet side. Its not as sickly as some, but still isnt great.

Consumed in Beirut Edinburgh with some beautiful Lebanese food.
Russett coloured with an easy big dark magnolia head.Firm fullish sappy-ish body. Some blunt bitterlike flavour which marries very well with the cherry element in the cherry wood. Maybe a bit on the confected side but still not bad at all.
Bottle. light brown pour with red tinges. Sweet woody aroma. Taste is sweet, warming alcohol, some berry taste.

Medium pale beige head. Clear deep red body. Perfumy fruity
butterscotch aroma with spicy bubblegum notes. Not bad, but a bit
artificial. Dry-sweet earthy spicy vanilla taste with fruity notes.
Mid-to-full body. Mild, soft, slick mouthfeel. Dryish roasty spicy
vanilla aftertaste with perfumy butterscotch and lavender notes.
Whoa. This is seriously artificial. (0.33l bottle, from wine
monopoly web order.)

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, wrapped in a nice carton box. Pours deep red, with a white fluffy head. Rather heavily carbonated.. Aroma of wood and cherry, very little alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium. Flavour is malty sweet with some cherry, the alcohol is not noticeable. Doesnt hit the high notes, but easy to drink and quite pleasant.

Transparent bottle in a cardboard box, 330 ml, best before July 2014, purchased at the LCBO, savoured March 17 2014; eye: auburn with a caramel hue, hazy, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: toffee, slight woody, light fruity, light alcohol, malt; mouth: toffee, slight woody, light fruity, light alcohol, malt, finale in malt with presence of alcohol, medium body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, a bit thin; overall: ordinary

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille transparente dans une boîte de carton, 330 ml, meilleure avant juillet 2014, achetée à la LCBO, savourée le 17 mars 2014; il : châtain avec une teinte caramel, voilée, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : toffee, très léger boisé, léger fruité, léger alcool, malt; bouche : toffee, très léger boisé, léger fruité, léger alcool, malt, finale en malt avec présence dalcool, corps moyen carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, un peu mince; en résumé : ordinaire

Flaske fra polet, på Holmens aktivitetsdag mars-14: nydelig gylden farge men kort skum. Søtlig dessertaktig aroma og smak med sirup/honning, vanilje, røde bær og delikat humlebalanse.De 8,3 er godt kamuflert i bildet. Velegnet til å avrunde et måltid, men vi må ubønnhørlig videre. Nå trenger vi noe som skjerper oss.
Clear amber. Short white head. Red berries and hops in aroma. Bittersweet taste of fruit and red berries. Caramel, plums and bitterness in aftertaste.

Beautiful aroma of malt and maple, appearance was top notch, a beautiful amber color with a yellow cream head. Unfortunately, not the greatest palatability for me, a bizarre bitter note that isnt working with the other predominant flavors of maple and malt. A decent beer no doubt but this is probably a one time buy for me.
330ml bottle from Vino Wines, Stockbridge, Edinburgh - clear amber brown, lively beige head, fruity, cherry aroma, irregular lacing, sweet, fruity, syrupy, cherry aftertaste
Bottle shared with Mr_H deep amber beer carmel and vanilla slight taste of fruit and cherry generally pretty sweet with slightly creamy finish
Bottle from Aldi; clear dark amber pour with beige head, boozy and malty aroma, taste has malts, caramel a hint of vanilla some fruity action.

Flaske 0,33l fra Vinmonopolet, Tromsø Sentrum. Drukket på RV124 18 Feb 14. Mørk gylden med et lite rødskjær. Høyt luftig skum med litt farge. Skummet varer noen minutter. Litt lacing. Sherryaroma. Smaken søt frukt. Plommer & svisker. Blir litt tørr etter hvert. Toner ut med mandelsmak.

25.4oz super bomber into a 16.9oz pilsner glass. Pours a beauty of a red roasted abmer. Head is glazing white, similar to the snow thats everywhere here, fresh, fluffy and full with about a half inch head and some nice lacing. Aroma is sweet, oak chips, apple, mild soft pear, cherry, raspberry, and dried figs. Taste is oak, sweet oak, sugared orange slices, raw vanilla, cherry flows in as expected, then this mayple syrup counteracts with the cherry and melds the offerings of this into a nice take on a scottish ale. Bitterness remains light and present, yet the cherry and vanilla flavor shines more with it. A very full and satyisfying brew, the sweetness is tame and marvels with the mayple syrup, and the woodchip aging only brings a satyisfying brilliance to this. Getting some rum in the aroma as well, abv is perfect for this excellent brew, big and bold and enjoyable. Very nice.

Appearance: clear amber-reddish brown, with a short creamy tan head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma: sweet caramel malts, vanilla, cherries in heavy syrup, a hint of booze and smoke. Taste: boozy burn at first, but as it comes to temperature, a lovely balance of vanilla, maple, caramel, cherries, toasted oak, light peat, and brown sugar.  Finish: lingering notes of light whiskey, cherries, and caramel over a hint of toasted wood. Notes: Quite nice. Flavors work well, especially closer to cellar temps. Big and sweet, almost like a scotch ale/barleywine hybrid.
Bottle.Bronze and claer with a small head. Not a lot of power considering its strength. In some ways it is quite deceptive. Different.

330ml bottle. pours an amber/orange with tiny head. aroma really does smell of smoky cherries so that would be the cherrywood. impressed with the taste too. thin and caramel like, sweet toffee with the smoky cherrywood there too. nice.

Bottle from sainsbury. 

Pours a lovely golden copper, initial smell is strong but that gives way to a taste of cherrys, maple and bourbon. 

Highly recommended with bbq brisket buns or pulled pork.

A stunning beer, but quite strong at 8.9%

330 ml bottle. Clear amber body with a moderate sized off-white head. Not very strong in aroma, but with a certain complexity. Malt, caramel and dry fruit with a soft touch of wood. Flavor is sweet malty, caramel, dry fruit and not much bitterness. Medium body, moderate in aftertaste. Not bad, some complexity, nice balanced.

330ml bottle. Clear dark amber colour, foamy tan head leaving lots of lacing and aroma of wood, oak, vanilla. Taste is sweet malty, cherry fruity, woody with spice, vanilla & oaky notes plus some light bitterness. Smooth slightly watery mouth feel, light to medium bodied, medium carbonation, spicy sourish finish. Quite OK.

Bottle at a tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Clear copper-amber with a small head. Aroma of malt, caramel, with light wood and cherries notes. Very sweet with caramel, maple syrup, toffee and wood. Medium-bodied.

330ml Bottle from Tesco (£2.39):
A nice beer and similar in a lot of ways to the breweries original beer. Smooth and quite easy to drink despite the huge alcohol content and the touches of alcohol dotted throughout the taste. Sweet and sugary with plenty going on to keep me interested and the warming alcohol feel to the palate was very nice.

Bottle. Its a clear bottle so no need to waste time on the description. Aroma is crazy sweet, very much like Red Swedish Berry candies <<shudder>>. The palate is much the same...BLECH!!!! Drain pour-- what a total failure for me.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 330ml bottle. Pours a hazy medium amber, with a moderate off-white head, which lasts well and leaves reasonable lacing. Toffee malt sits against a backdrop of bitter cherry and wood to create the aroma. Mild citrus blossom hops mix with faint bitter cherry up front. Toffee malt and a woody cherry pip flavour come into the mid-palate. Mild cherry appears in the finish. This is not bad, but the cherrywood doesnt really affect the beer in the same way that oak would. The flavour is there, but it doesnt really add to the beer all that much.
Pours rich copper with a small white top. Aroma is maple syrup and sweet oak with cherry. Taste is again very sweet with cherry and some wood notes and resinous from the syrup. Almost sickly sweet.

Bottle for Christmas from well meaning folks. Pours clear dark golden with small scummy whitish head. Sickly sweet bubblegum on the nose. Hint of banana. Cloying sweet off-caramel and woody notes. Thin body, medium carbonation. Doesn't taste 8.3%. Fairly unpleasant.
Bottle from vinmonopolet at home. Copper colour with small white head. Taste like all innis and gunn beers too sweet in my opinion.

Pours a crystal clear copper with a small white ring around the glass with just a few spots of lace on the glass. Aroma is cherry wood, maple syrup(not super artificial), moderate alcohol and overall just pretty sweet. Flavour is maple syrup, alcohol, cherry wood, toast, residual sugar and mild spice.

330ml bottle. Clear amber with off-white head. Smells grainy, lemony, oaky. Tastes up front of sweet toasted grain leading into charred oak, then occasionally a hint of maple comes through. Decent stuff, but base beer nor barrel influence really shone much.

Small bottle from Aldi for £1.99, I am quite fond of Innis & Gunn so decided to go for it! It pours brown and looks like any other bottled ale to my eyes, not much in the way of head but that didnt bother me. Smell ios malty, slightly sweet (Im guessing from the maple syrup but I wouldnt say I would tell unless I read that on the bottle) and cherry and wood. The taste is these things and quite nicely done and the alcohol strength is hidden. A good sipping beer which is slightly sweet finishing on a small amount of bitterness. This went rather nicely with the stilton cheese I was eating!

Bottle, from Aldi, Willerby. Deep amber gold, thin shortlived off white head and gentle condition. Initial sweet caramel and burnt toffee followed by a subdued wood smoke and vanilla note in the nose, quite sweet in the mouth with an oily mouthfeel and a tingle of burnt malt bitterness, more caramel emerging and low woody vanilla but quite unbalanced and dominated towards the end by a heavy spirity alcohol note, finish has a treacley sweetnessand a low woody bitterness lingering over a retronasal spirit kick
Lovely sweet aroma from this beer as good as I have encountered. The flavour is slightly less impressive but impressive nonetheless.

Bottle room temp.  8.3%  Dark orange / red, sparkling, small white head.  Smell - sweet, liquorice, oak, nail varnish remover.  Body - light, foamy, carbonation quite high.  Taste - mild malts, slight wood, nail varnish remover, coins, spicy finish with a little alcohol noticeable.  Its drinkable but uninspiring.  When I was new to drinking I thought Innis & Gunn was very good, and maybe my taste has changed.  Decent nonetheless.

Bottle. Black tea appearance with a thin foam. Aromas are toffee and maple syrup with marzipan and cherry syrup. Woody with caramel and hints of smoke. Traces of poo with floral notes. Flavours are cherry drop sweets with caramel and oak barrel. Vinous with lemon and maple syrup. Very much like the other Innis & Gunns. Slightly better than expected.

0.33l clear bottle. The beer is also clear and deep wood amber in color. It had a little eventually fading just off-white head. Smells nice and sweet. Caramel and toffee, candied apples, a little bit of wood, vanilla ice cream, lots of pear and some reeds. Its actually not to extremely sweet as I had expected in every way, and even somewhat complex on the nose. Nice. Oh, its really cloying and sweet in the taste alright. The maple syrup really has taken over this beer. Loaded with toffee, some sweet licorice, vanilla extract, canned pears with vanilla cream, hints of dark rum and wood. Damn, in some strange way Im kinda liking it, but its way to sweet and one directionend in the taste to be something I could drink lots of. 26.07.2013

big bottle provided by the Barbees .. . pours a medium tan .. . soft palate .. . light foam, lacing .. . maple, light young wood, caramel, and golden syrup .. . a tasty beer, one direction but still tasty .. . .  Zebras are just horses who escaped from prison.

Bottle: Poured a clear but dark amber color ale with a small foamy head with average retention and some lacing. Aroma of sweet malt notes with light woody notes. Taste is also quiet sweet which probably originated from the maple syrup. Body is light with medium carbonation. Too sweet for the style but nice used of cherry wood.
Sweet, a little bit more sweetness and then some marzipan. Did i mention some sweetness? After all of that then there is a huge metallic/artificial cherry flavour. Just not that nice

Appearance: Clear copper with 2 finger thick loose ivory head.
Aroma: Banana, vanilla, vinous, fruit cake, dried fig, hay, bread, cherry brandy.
Taste: Medium sweetness, low/medium bitterness and sourness.
Palate: Smooth light texture and body, average/prickly carbonation, lingering astringent sweet vanilla, dried fruit malty finish with alcohol warmth.
Comments: Tasty.

Bottle. It poursa clear dark amber body and with a small, dense off-white head leaving curtains. Caramel and a touch of brown sugar and some dried fruits. Some nuts. Lightly maple-ish. Pretty similar flavor, with a nice bitterness. Full body with a pleasant carbonation. Sweet, malty finish. Quite nice. 131129
Bottle. Amber with white head. Aroma of toffee and a little marzipan. Taste oftoffee, biscuit and cherry, wood. Sweet and a bit sticky.
Bottle at home... Copper... Thin tan head... Soft dry medicinal cherry nose... Sift fruits... Soft over sweet fruits... Big cherry... Light marzipan hints but WAY too sweet vanilla

Bottle, 6C. Clear amber with an off-white head thats soon a coat. Aroma of maple syrup, caramel, wood, cherry cough medicine, corn. Theres a plasticy note too, but it mostly dissipates. Really sweet. Alcohol is very well hidden. Cola, butterscotch, wood, maple syrup, struggling spicy bitterness. Medicinal cherry at the end. No better when it warmed to a sane temperature. Not for me at all. You could glaze a ham with it, though.

Bouteille claire de 330 ml achetée chez ANBL (Tracadie, N-B). Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel et de boisé. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe de fruitée et dérable. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #5317)

Sweet cherry malt herbal aroma. Clear amber colour poor head and lacing. Cherry malt hop flavour. Fizzy palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Slowbeer bottle (15-Nov-13) Lovely luscious sweet candy fruit aroma, but not sure if it is cherry. Clear red amber colour, low head and suds lacing. Big sweet cinnamon malt flavour. Sweet soft cherry cinnamon spice floral finish and sweet cherry aftertaste.
I love Innis and Gunn. I can see why some people may not appreciate them, but I like what they do and this beer is one of their better ones.

Pours a finger of foamy head on a clear amber colored body. 
It has a rich aroma of maple syrup followed by wood, toffee, dry barley and candy corn.
The taste is a nice lemon bitter and maple syrup sweet mixture. Its fairly mellow (in a good way) for an aged beer with maple syrup added. 
The texture has a stickiness to it with low to moderate carbonation.
Very enjoyable.

Pours a warm red with a little frothy golden head, very attractive. Nose is of red fruits, vanilla, caramel and maple wood. Theres toffee and more wood in the mouth, syrup sweetness, cherries and other red berries. This is very sweet with only mild bitterness detectable at all for me, not quite as well balanced as it could have been. A whole bottle did push my sweetness tolerance. There is very little sign of the booze though, and theres a good mouthfeel and carbonation. Medium body and a warm finish. Quite an odd one, would like it to be less powerfully sweet.
330ml bottle. Pours reddy brown with a small head. Aroma is cherry juice and woody vanilla. Taste has woody cherry to start with a strong cherry finish and vanilla on the aftertaste.
Bottle at TSODRBSG 13. Pale amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is malt, cherry, wood, caramel. Flavour is sweet. malt, cherry, vanilla, malt, caramel. Medium to full body. Nice beer.

Bottle sampled at Cajun Cafe Fall Beer Fest. Pours a clear amber-red with a white head. Nose is big sweetness, caramel, some maple, and some oaky vanilla. Flavor is similar- huge and overwhelming sweetness with some oaky vanilla, some fruit, and some caramel, but the blanket sweetness overpowers so much of this.

Clear dark amber with reddish hue pour with small off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel, oak and maple. Taste of malts, caramel, toffee, maple syrup, woody, slight peat, faint cherry coming through on the finish. Sweet beer somewhat masked by the higher carbonation. Bottle says serve between 4-6C, I think I enjoyed this more as it warmed, excellent beer.

Bottle at home. Has a golden dark amber colour and a small, light beige head. Aroma is filled with oak, liqour, dried fruit, berries, spices and caramel. Complex and nice. Sweet flavour with lots of caramel, bourbon and vanilla. Silky mouth feel, and has a light bitterness. Complex ale and is pretty sweet with lots of bourbon touches.

14th September 2013Clear amber beer with a tidy pale cream coloured head. Palate is smooth and a little soft. Fine minerally carbonation. Sweet creamy malt with oaky vanilla well integrated. Nice crystallised fruits - orange and cherry. Touch of marzipan. Finishes smooth and semi dry. Sweet and tasty.

Bottle 330ml. clear glass @ [ pre-TSODRBSG13 ], Ulfborg.Clear medium amber orange colour with a average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sweet malt, light toffee, cherry notes. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet with a average to long duration, artificial sweet, caramel, toffee, artificial fruit - cherry. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft. [20130830]
Medium brown in color. Rich notes of toffee with a hint of cherrywood. I find it leaves a bit of a bourbon feel on the palate. One of the better seasonal's from Innis & Gunn.
Rødbrun med beige skum som forsvinner fort. Fruktig, karamell, sherry, portvinlukt. Sherry og portvin også i smak. Lite kullsyre og bitterhet. Kan fort drikke denne igjen.
Rødbrun farge med lyst beige skum. Lukter karamell. Søtlig smak. Cherry taste. soft carbonation. Smaker godt at denne inneholder over 8% alkohol. Lang søtlig ettersmak.
Bonne odeur. Belle couleur. Goût très boisée et sucré avec des subtilités très intéressantes. Vraiment intéressante et de qualité

Poured into a snifter out of a 750ml bottle.

Pours a clear deep ruby with a thick one finger off-white head. Really good head retention and lacing.

The first note I get in the aroma is the very typical Innis and Gunn oakiness. There is some cherry in there that is faint along with a bit of butterscotch.

The flavor has that heavy familiar oak up front but there is more depth to it with this beer. Some cherry is there along with butterscotch and sweet caramel. The maple syrup is detectable in the sweetness that is present but the actual flavor is quite faint. Pretty thick mouthfeel with quite a bit of sweetness and a sticky finish.

Overall, a decent, somewhat complex beer but it still misses the mark for me. The sweetness is a bit much and somewhat limits drinkability. Still, a nice effort by Innis and Gunn.

From a bomber. Pours clear medium brown with a bubbly white head. Smells like cherry, bourbon, and wood. Light body and medium carbonation. Tastes fruity, like dry cherry, light raisin, and light raspberry.
330ml bottle from Appellation Wines - Cheers Ash! Pours amber, thin white head, big bubbles. Aromas are butterscotch and cherry wood. Taste is too sweet and woody. Tastes cheap. Lacks depth.

33cl bottle.
Appearance - golden amber with a decent creamy head.
Nose - somewhere between butterscotch and sweet cherry.
Taste - definitely cherry, maybe going into wood tannins, some cream. 
Palate - rich creamy body and texture, fairly elegant finish. 
Overall - good beer, one of their best.

Bottle. Pours clear, dark amber with creamy off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit, bread and cereal malts, woody notes, dark fruit esters, and some floral notes. Flavor is sweet, malty goodness with some great supporting woody notes, dark fruit esters, and light toast; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle shared by sonnycheeba. Pours clear amber with a medium, frothy off-white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is cherry, oak, dates, apple, honey and biscuit malt with light caramel notes. Flavor is malt dominant with oak and vanilla notes, dates and a sweet finish. Medium body and carbonation.

330ml bottle bought by the wife for my birthday. served at room temperature in a small tasting glass. Deep rich brown body with a tan head that rapidly disappeared. Aroma of toffee, kirsch and marzipan. Sweet rich flavour, with notes of apple, dried fruit, figs and almonds. The maple syrup is present, but nicely understated. Full bodied, oily palate, flat carbonation. Quite an alcoholic kick, but its not aggressive or intrusive, rather, its consistent with the style and overall experience. I gave up smoking years ago, but I could imagine enjoying this with a good cigar.
Not band. Quite sweet but storng in alcohol. NIce features and aroma or wood and whiskey.

Not much head ruby misty pour soft carbonation aromas caramel nut very wood like rich chocolate maple the flavours crisp sweet nutty caramel lots of maple richness the cherry wood enhancement is like rich wine the finish a delightful ale good to sit and enjoy the sweetness and body of the ale they are the best tastes
Bottle from Tesco, Durham. This is a red-brown beer with a sweet red fruity flavour, vanilla and oak notes, whisky and more sweetness, maple? And a powerful warming alcoholic kick to the finish.

Pours deep mahogany into a snifter. White head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Sweet toasted cherrywood and maple aromas. Medium bodied with strong wood, toasted caramel and syrup upfront turning dry and back to vanilla and wood in the lasting hot finish.

Pours dark amber/copper with a small fading head.
Nose shows sweet caramel and toffee, dry cut wood. Very sweet-smelling.
Sweet flavours too, big maple syrup notes, soft booze and sugary maple syrup. Too sweet, somewhat limited.
Carbonation could be higher.
Not bad, just far too sweet. Smells really nice and the barrel is noticeable.

Aroma of sweet caramel, vanilla, and dried fruit. Pours fairly well -clear, red/amber coloured-although the head doesnt last long. Medium bodied on the palate. I normally quite like Innis & Gunns beers but this one was a bit too sweet for my liking. Still worth trying nonetheless.

From notes: Poured clear copper-color with a 3-finger bone-colored head. Sweet cherry aroma mixed with a woody note. Body is medium, with a nice soft, lingering finish. Flavor has notes of wood, vanilla, leather and cherries. Allowing it to warm a bit allows the maple to come through in the finish. Very good, especially at the price point offered.

330 ml bottle. Clear red copper, foamy off-white head settles and fades. Aroma is fruity and malty, maple and cherry candy brandy. Sweet taste of caramel malts, maple, toffee and vanilla, fruity and boozy, like a cherry liqueur. All that sweetness masks any evidence of hops. Light carbonation, medium body, smooth fruity finish. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)
Bottle. Sweet vanilla and wood. Very sweet even by I&G standards. It reminds me of Original I&G from a few years back.

330 ml bottle from LCBO. Pours a clear dark copper colour with moderate-sized cream-coloured head. Aroma is lots of toffee, wood and light sweet maple. Flavour is big toffee/butterscotch, fruit, light woodiness and a faint hint of maple syrup. Syrupy mouthfeel. Nice.

330ml bottle (in a box - très chic) from Tesco - Deep maroon body, lasting white head. Looks pretty. Nose is caramel, alcohol, vanilla, stewed fruits. Body is mightily smooth, warm and one of the nicest fullest mouthfeels Ive had with I&G. Sweet ending, with the warmth of the booze coming in. Very impressed. very more-ish.

Sampled @ RB Danish Summer Gathering 2013 day 1, Ulfborg. Bottle. Clear orange color, small white head. Aroma is mostly sweetness, candy and some fruits. Taste alcohol, sweetish, slightly artificial fruityness. Medium body, firm carbonation.
33 cl clear bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with no head. Aroma is toasted malty and caramelish. Sweet, caramelish and mild vanilla note. Smooth fruity. Smooth fruity finish.
Bottle. Clear amber with small white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted and a little toffee. Flavour is Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, medium sweet and toffee.
Bottle @ TSODRBSG13, Ulfborg. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and fruity. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 300813
Bottle @ Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering, Ulfborg. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are caramel, malt, wood, fruits, maple syrup and hops.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, Kvadrat.Pours clear deep golden, with a mall white head.Aroma of caramel, toffee and wood. Taste is light sweet caramel, vanilla and toffee, alcohol burn at the finish.Too sweet.
Wood and leather on nose, also some dark fruit. Cherry and caramel on palate also some wood. Dont get the maple syrup as much but finish is slightly sweet. Interesting

Single from the LCBO, in their usual boxes for their special brews. Second Innis & Gunn of the night. Pours a clean deep amber colour with an off-white head, decent retention and a little lace. The aromas are mild, but pretty complex, changing as it breathes. Starts with dark fruits (plums, dates), then, roasted malts, burnt wood, butterscotch, cherry notes and other fruity malts. The mouthfeel is stuck between wet and syrupy, light and medium-bodied. A little on the sweet side, but not too much to kill things. Lots of the flavours seems like the nose. If there is any maple syrup in this, it is very well-blended. An interesting Scottish beer matured in the Cherrywood. Worth trying, just a little too sweet and syrupy to enjoy more. I think I prefer their original Canadian Oak matured beer.

Pours a deep maroon colour, with a small off white head. The aroma is rich and complex, with notes of wood, cherry, cough syrup, and scotch. The taste is also very complex and deep, with notes that include cherry, roasted maple, caramel, toffee and other rich deep malts. Wood, peat, and syrupy, the beer leaves an oily texture in the mouth and a sweet aftertaste.

This is an excellent beer, but is quite heavy. I could only ever drink one at a time, but an excellent brew non the less!

slight cloudy and red coppery colour eh! sweet caramel and some oak, although muted, and I actually do get some red fruity note on the aroma and a very sweet note. on the palate it is medium bodied at best, although slightly alcoholic that has a drying aspect to the brew. very nondescript overall but does offer some pleasure. meh, not the worst brew but not a collectors item as well.

One of their better ones, from LCBO. The base ale is not that great, the wood is very good. A little maple enhanced. Good drinkability.Somewhat too sweet. Maybe better in 6 months.A little head. Rating 666 of 13

Pours a clear copper with a very small and quickly disappearing white head. Smells like Cherry, maple, wood. Excelellent smell. Taste is overly sweet without much too balance it with. Wood finish. Decent carbonation. One of the best smelling beers I have had but taste was just ok

Bière orange cuivrée, parfaitement limpide, effervescence moyenne, surmontée dun col blanc cassé un peu mince qui disparaît assez rapidement. Arômes de malt caramélisé, vanille, boisé, céréale, bananes, pain. En bouche, cest à la fois pétillant et très onctueux, velouté, excellent palais. Au goût, cest surtout sucré et alcoolisé, caramel, sucre dorge, cerises au marasquin, pain aux bananes, boisé et alcool qui sintègre admirablement bien. Peut-être pas très complexe comme goût, mais cest rudement bon! Cette Innis & Gunn possède ce qui manque à sa consur «originale».

750 (more or less) capped bottle from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours orange copper with a creamy beige head. Aroma is roast malt with wood notes. Flavor is wood, malt, maple, mild spice. Not exactly dry, but not overtly sweet. The wood aspect, and maybe the hop, keep the sweet down. Its a lovely, mellow beer. Perhaps overly pretentious, but its an English ale.

330 mL bottle from LCBO served cold in a tulip glass. Clear deep amber, bright, with a full orange tan head. Very sweet, lots of caramel and toffee, fairly fruity, light earthiness, some wood, a touch sharp...spicy, toast and bread crust, a hint of vanilla, brown sugar. Medium plus body, restrained effervescence. Rich, sweet, fruity, nice wood accents, a bit of alcohol, a slightly harsh note; quite sweet, almost cloying, full, kinda harsh wood notes, lots of caramel, toffee, brown sugar, some booze, limited bitterness. One is enough.

My disdain for the standard version of Innis & Gunn caused me to be quite skeptical when try this beer. Was pleasantly surprised by this ale. Pours reddish auburn with a slightly red-tinged white head. Whiskey and fruit make for a wonderful nose. Flavor is a woody and sweet with strong whiskey notes. Beer is medium-light and relatively flat. Bottle - Greens Beer & Wine - Atlanta, GA

330ml clear bottle, from a box. \deep orange pour, clear. Tan head that leaves a sticky ring and a thin layer on the surface. Dark fruit notes and light toffee aromas. Taste has some dark fruit, a bit of vanilla, some sweetness. A bit of alcohol. Some toasty wood in the finish. Medium body, fine carbonation. Mellow but decent ale.

I enjoy Innis and Gunn beers. I found this was enjoyable, good taste, I did not find the 8.3% alc vol was overpowering that you can find in other beers, overall very good beer. I would drink this beer more often except it is a one time purchase for me as it was $4.95 for only a 330ml bottle at LCBO.

750 ml bottle. Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours a clear copper color with an inch light tan head. Head retention and lacing are both decent enough. The brew smells like cherries, wood, maple, and bready malt. I think the taste mostly follows the aroma, with the cherry and wood flavors being the strongest. Its a sweet, fruity ale. Theres also some caramel and candied fruit flavors noticeable. Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick and creamy with moderate carbonation. I liked this brew, its definitely worth a try. $7.99 a bottle.

On tap at 1808 Bistro in Delaware, Ohio. Poured into snifter.
I thought this would go nicely with dessert (beignets) and what a good choice!
Looked so very nice in snifter glass, deep red/amber with thin white head.
Aromas of malt, cherry, vanilla, wood, and brown sugar. Taste was much the same. Lots of sweet here but not cloyingly so. Mouthfeel was full and creamy.
Not something I would drink by the bottle or even all that often, but a small snifter with dessert or after dinner, Id have this again.
The aroma starts with a pleasent cherry maltiness. The taste has wonderful fruit notes with a touch of sweetness. There a touch of bitterness to balance the flavors. Extremely enjoyable style.
Reddish brown pour, light head. Flavors are sweet, woody, vanilla, hints of smoke, roasted nuts, bready flavors. Normally this brewery makes crap, but this was actually good.

Tallahassee, Fl - Fermentation Lounge - on tap. Dark copper pour, medium thick off white head, nice lacing. Aroma has some light cherry notes, a hint of Canadian Blended Whiskey. Flavor is mellow and smooth with some vanilla notes, some oaky goodness in the back end, some smooth whiskey notes without being overbearing. Nice thick mouthfeel. Pretty decent.

Sample at the Hills Market beer tasting on 07/25/2013. The beer pours a clear mahogany color with a thin white head that dissipates steadily. Short strings of lacing. Aroma of malt, oak and nuts. Medium-bodied with flavors of bready malt, nuts and wood. The finish is sweet with an earthy malt and wood aftertaste. Decent overall.

Another random misfired marketing ploy by Innis and Gunn. Hey, lets throw our average pale ale in some cherrywood casks and see id suckers in Canada will but it. Well even give it a box and charge more to increase the hype. Too sweet, cherry doesnt do anything to help caremelizesd malt. Bottle.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep copper-hued amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Very nice. Nose is caramel, toffee, cream, wood, mild red berries, vanilla and hints of syrup (maple, maybe?). Taste is caramel, sweet syrup (more pronounced maple now), vanilla, toffee, hints of red berries and faint woody notes. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Too sweet, as is mostly the case with I & G, but fair enough.

Pours auburn. Aroma of vanilla, slightly fruity brown sugar and bourbon. Initial taste is sweet, definitely get the addition of the maple and bourbon. Has a lot of depth. Not a huge fan of bourbon so this is not going to appeal to me as it would others, but for what it is it is well done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear, 750mL bottle. Light brown, copper color. Thin ring, white fizz. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, loads of buttery toffee, deep earthiness. Definitely has a sweet toffee flavor, caramel sweetness, hints of Canadian Whisky sugars. Finishes with a maple flavor (not cloying like pancake syrup) light/thin/fresh maple. Some light toasted malt notes. Overall, very sessionable. Thin bodied. Loads of character, but you got to be looking for it. It Crown Royal made a beer... (3771)

Poured from 330mL bottle. Clear copper orange colour with off-white head. Aroma has the usual Innis & Gunn vanilla and toffee aroma, but also has a very distinct wood aroma and some toasted malt. Taste is very similar to the original as well, but with a small hit of alcohol and a slightly woody finish.

Pours a burnt orange colour with a short lived head. The aroma is sweet, lightly buttery, malty toffee, caramel, light note of cinnamon hearts. The flavour is also sweet, malty caramel and toffee, light butter, its rather straight forward, but easy drinking and interesting enough.

Draft to taster. Looks solid; a transparent amberish orange with light beige lacing. Smells malty with plenty of caramel with notes of wood and maple syrup. Tastes like it smells with a good mouthfeel. Enjoyable.

330 mL. 8.3%. Clear golden pour with a bubbly creamy white head that bubbles away quickly.. Aroma is toasted malt, caramel, maple syrup. the usual bourbon cask caramel malt character that makes I&G unique. Taste is quite smooth, lightly hopped and rich in roast malt flavour. Finish develops a little of the cherrywood character, in colour, and a stickiness from the maple syrup, and that oaky tinge as you swallow. Delicious.

Picked up at Bottle No. 121. Aroma: caramel, roasty, cereal, bread. Appearance: red, clear, frothy. Taste: light sweetness, biscuits. Palate: medium body, lively fizz, with thick head. Unique flavor with the cherrywood but still Innis & Gunn Scottish flavor. Very good beer.

Pour a clear medium reddish amber with low carbonation, not much for head. Aroma is sweet, smells of cherry wood, and some malt. Taste is malty - some toffee, some pale, some wood (oakish), with a slight earthy bitterness. Warming mouthfeel. Finishes sweet, with the wood notes and a slight earthy bitterness. Quite good. One of the best of the I&G specials...

Right out of the bottle
yes maple syrup and bananas with a very light lime/lemon hop slight aftertaste. A bit too sweet for me. Might taste good on pancakes if you make a reduction.
Creamy and a smooth sweet caramel. Maybe plum/dried prune style honey on the palate. Low carbonation
Alcohol is well hidden for 8.3%. Very drinkable but in a maple marshmallow with a hint of lemon way. Cannot taste any wood or cherry but I finished a chimay a little while ago.
Still a well crafted beer but more of an aperitif type and having a one off is enough. Iwas thinking colder might be better but I suspect it would even intensify the honey sweet on the mouth.
Quality beer and my ratings are low mostly because I likes my sours. I was hoping for more of the cherry the box mentions

On tap at Taco Mac. Translucent cherrywood color with a foamy tan head. Aroma of cherry, wood, sweet malts, and dark fruits. Light and creamy texture. Not as thick as expected. Taste of cherry, old wood, syrup, and roasted malts. Has a long lasting rich cherry finish. Very enjoyable. A nice sipper.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 18.07.2013, 0,33l bottle @ home:
Nice mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly sweet, caramel malts, almond essence, nuts, toffee, oak, alcohol, paint, grass. Taste is sweet and slightly harsh, caramel malts, sugar, almond essence, alcohol, grass, oak, toffee. Medium bitterness. Not my favorite.

Ruddy amber pour with a thin white head. The aroma is quite sweet. Lots of woodiness, vanilla and some sweet toffee character. There is a little bit of earthy hop bitterness and a bit of soft fruitiness as well. There is a touch of soft bitterness cutting the malt sweetness. Lightly woody with an interesting wood note. Im kind of a sucker for these beers.

Bottle from the lcbo. Clear amber pour, small beige head. Faint butter aroma, light oak, some vanilla and caramel malts. Light hints of toffee in the finish, some solid bread malts. Light hops, and more wood, with the typical butter innis finish. Not bad.

Snifter on tap at Neons, $8. Mostly clear darker red orange amber color. Thin khaki head, leaves pretty good lace. Good cherry, wood flavors along with the light caramel malt, moderate spicy flavors. Sweeter taste, light bitter. Little tropical fruit, dark fruit. Light candy. Medium-plus body, smooth lighter crisp carbonation. Kind of a creamy texture, pretty nice. Good longer aftertaste. Bit of vanilla. Tasty scotch ale.

Draft. Poured dark reddish amber with an creamy off-white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Good complex sweet earthy malt and cherry wood aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Good well balanced sweet malt and wood flavor with a long finish with a small alcohol tone. Very good complex brew.
7/13/13. 750mL thanks to Brian! Clear amber red. Lots of caramel, plenty of wood, bitter wood, some sweet fruits and a dash of skunk. Meh.

Strong fruit malt aroma. Cherry pour with a thin dissapating lace. Sweet syrup, maple, caramel and butterscotch flavour. Sweet syrup texture. Just into the style. Im sure if you like this its very good.

Smells strong like a cherry brandy or a nice port wine. appearance is clear amber like a Boston lager, but dont be fooled, the taste is completely unique. Wooded barrel and honey notes like a mead and a peaty whiskey.

330ml bottle. Copper colour, like a dark maple syrup, filtered, small eggshell head. Aroma of wood, cherry, vanilla, toffee. Taste is much the same, with some more sweetness from the maple. Body is a bit syrupy. Overall, maybe a bit too sweet for my ideal, but still very good.

330 mL bottle. Pours a rich copper amber with a patchy head. Aromas of cherry, oak, vanilla, maple and rich caramel malt. Fairly sweet with an ever so slight hop finish, medium carbonation, medium-full body and slight alcohol bite. A bit sweet for my liking, but good complexity.

Bottle. Dark and clear ruby-amber with a small white head. Very inviting aroma of dark cherry, vanilla, toffee, and a subtle woodiness. Medium bodied. Pleasant - if just a touch too sweet - flavour that has all of the notes promised in the aroma, along with a bit of maple. Slightly boozy finish that develops of sweet cherry cough drop character as it warms. A really enjoyable beer, and one of the best of the limited releases Ive tried from I&G.

330ml bottle. Faint aroma, though thankfully none of the typical I&G skunkiness. Pours a silky tight tan head which surprised me as well. Lots of lace. Tawny amber (Lovibond 16) with perfect clarity. Taste is bold!! Malty and sweet like caramel with a hint of the unique wood aging taste of their regular oak barrel fare. Actually very surprised at the results here. This turns out to be their best outing yet!!

Bottle 330 ml 
Aroma: soft aromatic, fresh ,sour cherry sweetness with refined alcohol with raspberry sweetness. 7+ 
Look: clear amber with medium plus tanned creamy top. 4- 
Taste: sweet candy wrap on scotch ale mid. I wish to see some smoke here. Still very refined choice. Bit too syrupy like sweetness.
330 ml bottle. Pours a clear mahogany with medium head. Aromas of sugar, leather, toasted malts, and light wood. Flavors of of vanilla, sweet brown sugar, and green wood.

330 mL bottle, Darker than their usual fare, and actually has a nice little head on it. A little sweet on the nose, but not cloyingly so. Its probably my imagination, but I smell maraschino cherries as well. kinda tastes how it smells, but with an added touch of booze. A little whiskeyish perhaps. Better than most of theirs.

Crystal clear cherry/caramel pour with off-white head that doesnt really last long. Toffee, fruit and wood on the nose with slight whiskey notes. Toffee, cherry, spice, wood on the palate. Nicer than the other brews Ive had from these cats.
Probably the best Innis and Gunn product Ive had so far.  The malty sweetness and cherry wood is noticeable on the the forefront.  Very sweet with some fruit presence on the finish.

Bottle shared with northropfrye. Rich yet light fruity aroma. Caramel toffee colour, not a lot of head. Very delicious taste. Notes of cherry. Occasionally reminds me of the childrens cough syrup I enjoyed as a child, but always delicious.

Red body with off white head and some nice lacing. Quite instense aroma of whiskey, smoke, sweet fruit. Taste is also sweet fruit, definite whiskey, abv is masked fairly well, though you do get some booziness here. A little hops to balance this out would have made this beer amazing. As it is, its pretty damn good. One of the better beers by Innis and Gunn.
Pours Amber.  Aromas of sweet vanilla, toffee, cherry cough syrup. The cherry wood flavours come through with that classic innis and gunn sweet toffee and vanilla. Warm boozy finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2014 Pours a clear amber with a small frothy white head that dissipates quickly but leaves nice lacing. Aroma of sweet dried fruits, wood, caramel, slight maple and some alcohol. Taste is malty syrupy sweetness, fruity, woody and a blast of alcohol flavor and warming on the finish.  Overall a nice beer but just too much booze, I see this being better in a year or so.

Update: Beer has definitely subdued somewhat from the alcohol and is more well balanced than it was before.

330ml bottle pours amber in color with a finger of white head that settles down to reveal some spotty lacing on the glass.  Aroma is caramel and hints of maple.  Taste is a malty and fruity sweetness with a grassy and herbal hop bitterness.  Medium bodied with average carbonation.  Overall, a decent brew, but nothing spectacular.
